title: How do we create a better economy?

multiple-choice.question: According to economist Kate Raworth, what is the main problem with the current economic system?

options.label: A
options.text: It focuses too much on the environment.

options.label: B
options.text: It ignores the unpaid caring work of parents.

options.label: C
options.text: It is addicted to endless growth.

options.label: D
options.text: It does not account for the value of communities.

multiple-choice.question: What did Simon Kuznets, the economist, say about the limitations of GDP?

options.label: A
options.text: He said it was the perfect measure of a nation's wealth.

options.label: B
options.text: He said it was a good measure of the flow of economic value.

options.label: C
options.text: He said it told us nothing about the unpaid caring work of parents.

options.label: D
options.text: He said it was a measure of the welfare of a nation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of Kate Raworth's "doughnut economics"?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase GDP growth while reducing resource use.

options.label: B
options.text: To leave nobody in poverty while not overshooting the planet's limits.

options.label: C
options.text: To prioritize economic growth over environmental sustainability.

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce poverty while ignoring environmental degradation.

multiple-choice.question: According to Kate Raworth, what is the key to understanding the interdependence of the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on economic growth.

options.label: B
options.text: Understanding the deep interdependence of our world.

options.label: C
options.text: Ignoring the environment.

options.label: D
options.text: Prioritizing individual interests over collective well-being.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of Kate Raworth's "doughnut economics"?

options.label: A
options.text: To prioritize economic growth over environmental sustainability.

options.label: B
options.text: To balance human needs with the planet's limits.

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce poverty while ignoring environmental degradation.

options.label: D
options.text: To increase GDP growth while reducing resource use.

title: Why plague doctors wore beaked masks

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: The sibling rivalry that divided a town - Jay Van Bavel and Dominic Packer

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary goal of the minimal group paradigm developed by Henri Tajfel and his collaborators?

options.label: A
options.text: To investigate the effects of group membership on individual behavior

options.label: B
options.text: To study the impact of stereotypes on group dynamics

options.label: C
options.text: To examine the minimal conditions required to turn people against each other

options.label: D
options.text: To analyze the relationship between group size and group cohesion

multiple-choice.question: In the minimal group experiments, what was the control condition designed to achieve?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a conflict-free baseline for further research

options.label: B
options.text: To introduce a resource conflict between groups

options.label: C
options.text: To eliminate group bias by ensuring participants interacted

options.label: D
options.text: To create a scenario where group membership was determined by a skill

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the minimal group experiments, even when group membership was determined by a coin flip?

options.label: A
options.text: Participants showed no in-group bias

options.label: B
options.text: Participants showed a moderate level of in-group bias

options.label: C
options.text: Participants consistently gave more resources to members of their own group

options.label: D
options.text: Participants showed no difference in resource allocation between groups

multiple-choice.question: What theory was proposed by Tajfel and his colleagues to explain the results of the minimal group experiments?

options.label: A
options.text: Social identity theory

options.label: B
options.text: Group polarization theory

options.label: C
options.text: Social exchange theory

options.label: D
options.text: Social influence theory

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential outcome of bringing individuals together in a new group?

options.label: A
options.text: It will always lead to increased group cohesion and reduced in-group bias

options.label: B
options.text: It will temporarily help people overcome entrenched biases

options.label: C
options.text: It will have no effect on group dynamics

options.label: D
options.text: It will always lead to increased conflict between groups

options.label: B
options.text: Calcite is more soluble and can adapt to acidic environments, while aragonite is more stable and less prone to dissolving over time

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Aragonite is made of a different chemical composition than calcite

options.label: C

title: How do we determine the value of a life? - Rebecca L. Walker

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The difficulty in diagnosing smallpox.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Because animals are more susceptible to smallpox than humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Because animals are closer biological relatives to humans.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether animals should be used in research at all.

options.label: C
options.text: How to balance the needs of humans and animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether it's morally justifiable to harm animals to protect humans.

options.label: C

title: Why the Moon turns red during a total lunar eclipse

options.label: D

options.label: C

title: Is capitalism actually broken?

multiple-choice.question: What determines whether an economic machine is capitalist, communist, socialist, or something else?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.text: The two dials that control who owns the capital and government control.

options.label: D
options.text: The one dial that controls who owns the capital.

options.label: D
options.text: No regulations, and economists believed that capitalism's "invisible hand" would produce catastrophic outcomes.

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

options.label: B
options.text: Do we need to tear the machine down and build a new one from scratch?

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D
options.text: Neither A nor B

title: Is inequality inevitable?

multiple-choice.question: What is the Gini index, and what does it measure?

options.label: A
options.text: The Gini index is a measure of a country's economic growth, and it measures the country's GDP.

options.label: B
options.text: The Gini index is a measure of economic inequality, and it compares the income or wealth distribution of a perfectly equal society to the actual income or wealth distribution.

options.label: C
options.text: The Gini index is a measure of a country's population growth, and it measures the country's birth rate.

options.label: D
options.text: The Gini index is a measure of a country's environmental quality, and it measures the country's air and water pollution.

multiple-choice.question: What are some ways that capitalist countries can choose to reduce economic inequality?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing taxes on the wealthy and providing government transfers to low-income individuals.

options.label: B
options.text: By reducing taxes on the wealthy and eliminating government transfers to low-income individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: By implementing socialism or communism.

options.label: D
options.text: By increasing the minimum wage and providing education and healthcare to all citizens.

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of progressive taxation on economic inequality?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases economic inequality by allowing the wealthy to keep more of their income.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces economic inequality by taking a larger share of income from the wealthy and redistributing it to low-income individuals.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on economic inequality.

options.label: D
options.text: It increases economic inequality by allowing the wealthy to pay lower taxes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of inheritance taxes, and how do they affect economic inequality?

options.label: A
options.text: Inheritance taxes are used to increase economic inequality by allowing the wealthy to pass on their wealth to their heirs.

options.label: B
options.text: Inheritance taxes are used to reduce economic inequality by limiting the amount of wealth that can be passed on to heirs.

options.label: C
options.text: Inheritance taxes have no effect on economic inequality.

options.label: D
options.text: Inheritance taxes are used to increase economic growth by allowing the wealthy to invest their wealth in businesses.

multiple-choice.question: What is the digital divide, and how does it affect economic inequality?

options.label: A
options.text: The digital divide refers to the gap between those who have access to the Internet and those who do not, and it increases economic inequality by limiting access to information and opportunities.

options.label: B
options.text: The digital divide refers to the gap between those who have access to high-speed internet and those who do not, and it has no effect on economic inequality.

options.label: C
options.text: The digital divide refers to the gap between those who have access to education and those who do not, and it reduces economic inequality by providing access to education.

options.label: D
options.text: The digital divide refers to the gap between those who have access to healthcare and those who do not, and it has no effect on economic inequality.

title: The Boltzmann brain paradox - Fabio Pacucci

multiple-choice.question: What is the Boltzmann brain paradox?

options.label: A
options.text: A paradox that questions the existence of the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: A paradox that suggests the universe has existed for an infinite time.

options.label: C
options.text: A paradox that questions whether a person's memories are real or artificial.

options.label: D
options.text: A paradox that questions the likelihood of extremely unlikely events in the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the second law of thermodynamics, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A law that states that closed systems tend towards order.

options.label: B
options.text: A law that states that closed systems tend towards disorder.

options.label: C
options.text: A law that states that the universe has existed for an infinite time.

options.label: D
options.text: A law that states that the universe will eventually return to its original state.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the likelihood of a brain forming from random quantum fluctuations?

options.label: A
options.text: It is extremely likely.

options.label: B
options.text: It is slightly likely.

options.label: C
options.text: It is incredibly unlikely.

options.label: D
options.text: It is impossible.

multiple-choice.question: What is the resolution to the Boltzmann brain paradox, as described in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The universe has existed for an infinite time.

options.label: B
options.text: The universe has not existed forever, but rather time and space started with a Big Bang.

options.label: C
options.text: The paradox is still remains unsolved.

options.label: D
options.text: The paradox is not relevant to our understanding of the universe.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Boltzmann brain paradox in contemporary cosmology?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides a clear explanation for the origin of the universe.

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a bar that models have to rise to, in order to be considered valid.

options.label: C
options.text: It is no longer relevant to modern cosmological theories.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a completely unrelated concept to cosmology.
